title: Photo Deconstruction: Creating a Monochromatic Red Fashion Image
summary: Lindsay Adler breaks down a fashion photoshoot centered around the color red. She explains how to build a set that adds depth, demonstrates a lighting setup mixing hard and soft light, and details the post-processing workflow required to achieve rich, luxurious colors and a monochromatic look.

steps.action: Construct a corner set using two textured red backdrops to create depth and converging lines.
Position the main light to create a focused pocket of high-contrast light on the subject's face and torso.
Add a fill light to lift the shadows and soften the overall contrast of the scene.
Select a versatile zoom lens to capture full-length, 3/4, and close-up shots without changing lenses.
Apply global adjustments in raw processing, specifically adding contrast to make the red tones appear richer.
Use the Color Editor to unify the reds and desaturate/lighten the orange tones to correct skin color in a red environment.
Perform final retouching, including extending the background, mirroring texture for symmetry, and dodging and burning.

key_takeaways: Building a physical corner with backdrops prevents the image from looking flat and adds dimension.
Rich, deep red colors often require adding contrast and darkening the image in post-processing; bright reds can look washed out or orange.
To achieve a monochromatic look, it is crucial to separate skin tones from the environment by desaturating and lightening the oranges.
Using a zoom lens (like a 24-105mm) provides flexibility to change composition quickly during a fashion shoot.
